docs.title: Connecting to Tableland
docs.description: Access the Tableland network by first connecting to the base chain.

frontMatter.title: Connecting to Tableland
frontMatter.description: Access the Tableland network by first connecting to the base chain.
frontMatter.synopsis: Tableland is an extension of the chains it supports. Namely, every table creation and write occurs through on-chain actions, so it is a requirement for every developer to connect and interact with a supported blockchain. From there, reads happen off-chain by way of directly accessing the Tableland node network.

docs.title: Creating tables
docs.description: Learn how to create tables from the SDK.

frontMatter.title: Creating tables
frontMatter.description: Learn how to create tables from the SDK.
frontMatter.synopsis: All tables are created through on-chain actions that create a table (ERC721 token). The SDK abstracts this from the developer's point of view, but it's important to understand this context for why a chain connection is required for table creation.

docs.title: Getting started
docs.description: Get up an running with the Tableland SDK.

frontMatter.title: Getting started
frontMatter.description: Get up an running with the Tableland SDK.
frontMatter.synopsis: Dive into the basics for connecting, creating, writing, and reading from tables. More detailed information is provided in subsequent overviews, but the details provided here should allow developers to quickly understand where to start.

docs.title: Reading tables
docs.description: Openly readable tables by your applications.

frontMatter.title: Reading tables
frontMatter.description: Openly readable tables by your applications.
frontMatter.synopsis: Reading from tables is entirely open (for anyone), allowing for true composability. Write SQL qeuries—but with some limitations that are due to the nature of decentralized networks and deterministic requirements.

docs.title: Quick start
docs.description: Experiment with creating, editing, and querying tables from the comfort of the command line.

frontMatter.title: Quick start
frontMatter.description: Experiment with creating, editing, and querying tables from the comfort of the command line.
frontMatter.synopsis: The JavaScript / TypeScript SDK allows developers to create tables on their chain of choice. Connect, create, and then interact with your tables thereafter with table writes and reads.

docs.title: Writing to tables
docs.description: Mutate your table values with additional access control.

frontMatter.title: Writing to tables
frontMatter.description: Mutate your table values with additional access control.
frontMatter.synopsis: Table values can be mutated by the table owner or provisioned actors.

docs.title: FAQs
docs.description: Review commonly asked questions about the Tableland network and community.

frontMatter.title: FAQs
frontMatter.description: Review commonly asked questions about the Tableland network and community.

docs.title: Considerations & tradeoffs
docs.description: Tableland offers a new solution to suboptimal web3 data storage standards.

frontMatter.title: Considerations & tradeoffs
frontMatter.description: Tableland offers a new solution to suboptimal web3 data storage standards.
frontMatter.synopsis: Selecting the chain to deploy tables on has a significant impact on the subsequent usage of the table. But before selecting a chain to then use Tableland’s capabilities, it may be helpful to consider the alternatives to Tableland in the first place.

docs.title: Open beta
docs.description: Use Tableland on testnet and mainnet chains while the protocol is in development.

frontMatter.title: Open beta
frontMatter.description: Use Tableland on testnet and mainnet chains while the protocol is in development.
frontMatter.synopsis: The Tableland network is actively being developed and plans to launch a production (mainnet) in 2024. Prior to that launch, the protocol can still be used on supported chains, but its important to note what's in store in the future.

docs.title: Data availability & network state
docs.description: Understand the basic model behind on-chain writes and off-chain reads.

frontMatter.title: Data availability & network state
frontMatter.description: Understand the basic model behind on-chain writes and off-chain reads.
frontMatter.synopsis: Blockchains are designed so that anyone can run some arbitrary programs and share computation; they are not designed to be databases. With a hybrid model, applications can inherit components (like security & execution) from the host chain while making the data itself dynamic & accessible on the Tableland network.

docs.title: Use cases
docs.description: A series of general use cases to consider.

frontMatter.title: Use cases
frontMatter.description: A series of general use cases to consider.
frontMatter.synopsis: This page identifies some potential use cases. It is non-exhaustive but provides guidelines / considerations for where developers can use Tableland, and as always, consider the host chain as part of the use case criteria (e.g., Ethereum is more expensive to write to than an L2).

docs.title: What is Tableland?
docs.description: Learn about the basics of the Tableland network.

frontMatter.title: What is Tableland?
frontMatter.description: Learn about the basics of the Tableland network.
frontMatter.synopsis: Tableland is a web3 native SQL database that can be used on EVM chains like Ethereum and Layer 2 solutions. It helps extend data storage using SQL while offloading accessibility to a decentralized network of validator nodes that watch the host chain for updates, which is where SQL mutation data is made available.

docs.title: Overview
docs.description: Learn about what Tableland is.

frontMatter.title: Overview
frontMatter.description: Learn about what Tableland is.
frontMatter.synopsis: Structured Query Language (SQL) is a language that allows developers to interact with databases for extracting and mutating values.

docs.title: Databases & SQL
docs.description: Briefly look under the hood at relational databases.

frontMatter.title: Databases & SQL
frontMatter.description: Briefly look under the hood at relational databases.
frontMatter.synopsis: The network is akin to a bunch of databases communicating & agreeing with one another about things that happened on-chain. Although it's an oversimplification, the core premise behind it all is a relational database, which isn't flashy by any means but adds a new dimension to web3 storage.

docs.title: Related topics
docs.description: Learn about what Tableland is.

frontMatter.title: Related topics
frontMatter.description: Learn about what Tableland is.
frontMatter.synopsis: Structured Query Language (SQL) is a language that allows developers to interact with databases for extracting and mutating values.

docs.title: Vision & roadmap
docs.description: The protocol is still being developed and progressively decentralized.

frontMatter.title: Vision & roadmap
frontMatter.description: The protocol is still being developed and progressively decentralized.
frontMatter.synopsis: Tableland's inception came in late 2021. It's consistently growing in terms of the core protocol itself and development activity on top of the protocol, and there is still plenty in store in the coming months and years.

docs.title: URI encoding
docs.description: SQL queries written at the query endpoint must have the proper encoding.

frontMatter.title: URI encoding
frontMatter.description: SQL queries written at the query endpoint must have the proper encoding.
frontMatter.synopsis: Developer can write SQL read statement using the query REST API. This creates a truly flexible API where the response object can have fully custom keys that are hydrated with query values.

docs.title: Incrementing values automatically
docs.description: Tableland allows developers to automatically increment a cell, with some restrictions.

frontMatter.title: Incrementing values automatically
frontMatter.description: Tableland allows developers to automatically increment a cell, with some restrictions.
frontMatter.synopsis: Developers often want to insert a row with a cell that automatically increases by a value of 1. There are some intricacies to be aware of, but this is fully possible with Tableland SQL and makes it easy to insert a row with an automatically generated identifier.

docs.title: Maintainers
docs.description: Core contributors to the Tableland protocol's documentation.

frontMatter.title: Maintainers
frontMatter.description: Core contributors to the Tableland protocol's documentation.

docs.title: How to contribute
docs.description: Get involved and contribute to the Tableland ecosystem.

frontMatter.title: How to contribute
frontMatter.description: Get involved and contribute to the Tableland ecosystem.
frontMatter.synopsis: Tableland welcomes new collaborators and contributions. The protocol is constantly growing and looking for help from community members, and we've open sourced all of our code, documentation, and tutorials to make this possible. Learn more about where to begin and stylistic guidelines & features about the docs site, in particular.

docs.title: Style guide
docs.description: Learn the ins and outs of contributing to the Tableland docs site.

frontMatter.title: Style guide
frontMatter.description: Learn the ins and outs of contributing to the Tableland docs site.
frontMatter.synopsis: The docs site is built using Docusaurus, a static site generator developed by Meta that is specifically designed for documentation. It offers a number of features, including MDX support (embed JSX in markdown) and various content-friendly plugins. Please ensure you follow the guidelines on writing style as well.

docs.title: Arbitrum
docs.description: An overview of using Arbitrum with Tableland.

frontMatter.title: Arbitrum
frontMatter.description: An overview of using Arbitrum with Tableland.
frontMatter.synopsis: Arbitrum is one of the EVM-compatible Layer 2 solutions that Tableland currently supports. Check out the overview of what this network is and relevant information when using it.

docs.title: Ethereum
docs.description: An overview of using Ethereum with Tableland.

frontMatter.title: Ethereum
frontMatter.description: An overview of using Ethereum with Tableland.
frontMatter.synopsis: Ethereum and its EVM is what drives Tableland's approach for chain compatibility. With its data and network hardness, it's a great case for many projects, but not all use cases can occur here due to cost constraints.

docs.title: Using a local chain
docs.description: An overview of using a Hardhat node and a local Tableland instance.

frontMatter.title: Using a local chain
frontMatter.description: An overview of using a Hardhat node and a local Tableland instance.
frontMatter.synopsis: Developing locally should happen as a step prior to deploying to any testnet and/or mainnet. Developers can use Local Tableland to accomplish this, which spins up a Hardhat node for a local Tableland node to use.

frontMatter.synopsis: Optimism is one of the EVM-compatible Layer 2 solutions that Tableland currently supports. Check out the overview of what this network is and relevant information when using it.

docs.title: Choosing a chain
docs.description: Selecting a base chain is an important step in any application’s design and, especially, for tables.

frontMatter.title: Choosing a chain
frontMatter.description: Selecting a base chain is an important step in any application’s design and, especially, for tables.
frontMatter.synopsis: Chain selection makes a significant impact on a table’s usability. Choose a chain that’s too slow or expensive, and it won’t be feasible for table writes to occur frequently. Deploy a cross-chain data model for value layering purposes, and certain on-chain access control features are lost.

docs.title: Local development & testing
docs.description: Build with Local Tableland to quickly iterate with Tableland using a local environment.

frontMatter.title: Local development & testing
frontMatter.description: Build with Local Tableland to quickly iterate with Tableland using a local environment.
frontMatter.synopsis: Developers can leverage a local-only instance of the Tableland network that spins up a local Hardhat node in the process. This allows for quickly iterating while developing (create, write, and read local tables) and also allows for integrating Local Tableland into your testing flow.

docs.title: Development tools
docs.description: Leverage various tooling to ease the developer experience.

frontMatter.title: Development tools
frontMatter.description: Leverage various tooling to ease the developer experience.
frontMatter.synopsis: There are quite a few different tools that can be used while developing with Tableland. Each of these are intended to further smooth the developer experience and make it easier to use the various APIs and clients built on top of the protocol.

docs.title: Tableland Rigs
docs.description: A developer-first NFT, inherently rewarding builders and community members of the Tableland network.

frontMatter.title: Tableland Rigs
frontMatter.description: A developer-first NFT, inherently rewarding builders and community members of the Tableland network.
frontMatter.synopsis: Rigs are a generative collection of 3k NFTs designed for those who build on Tableland. They set a foundation to help reward developers for building high value applications and to those contributing to the ecosystem as a whole.

docs.title: Response times
docs.description: Processing times for creates & writes are largely dependent on the base chain, but read responses are standard.

frontMatter.title: Response times
frontMatter.description: Processing times for creates & writes are largely dependent on the base chain, but read responses are standard.
frontMatter.synopsis: Tableland is always dependent on the base chain for the speed at which transactions are finalized. For each chan, nodes listen and process emitted events. When that data is materialized in Tableland node's SQLite databases, it becomes immediately accessible and queryable with high responsiveness.

docs.title: Dynamic NFT with Chainlink Automation
docs.description: Leverage Chainlink for automated NFT mutations.

frontMatter.title: Dynamic NFT with Chainlink Automation
frontMatter.description: Leverage Chainlink for automated NFT mutations.
frontMatter.synopsis: The Chainlink network can help make autonomous on-chain calls and enable truly dynamic NFTs. All of the logic can be created with smart contracts and registered in the Chainlink automation portal, enabling dynamic NFTs using on-chain logic, only.

previous.title: Creating a dynamic NFT with p5.js

docs.title: Creating a dynamic NFT with p5.js
docs.description: Use p5.js to render data from an NFT that holds global game state in a table.

frontMatter.title: Creating a dynamic NFT with p5.js
frontMatter.description: Use p5.js to render data from an NFT that holds global game state in a table.
frontMatter.synopsis: We want to now write a simple web app that will be used to dynamically render a single NFT in our collection. When the NFT renders, the web app should check the requested token, grab the latest data from Tableland, and render some dynamic content.

previous.title: Build a dynamic NFT in Solidity

docs.title: Build a dynamic NFT in Solidity
docs.description: Create an on-chain game that uses SQL queries to create and populate a table of game state.

frontMatter.title: Build a dynamic NFT in Solidity
frontMatter.description: Create an on-chain game that uses SQL queries to create and populate a table of game state.
frontMatter.synopsis: Tableland enables ownership & on-chain rules to dictate table state mutation. For every mutation, the data is accessible with off-chain queries that can be displayed in an interface, such as an NFT-based game board. This tutorial walks through the basics of Solidity ERC721s and an app with shared state.

metadata.title: Welcome
metadata.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

blogPosts.content:
[Docusaurus blogging features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) are powered by the [blog plugin](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog).

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the `blog` directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to `authors.yml`.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

- `2019-05-30-welcome.md`
- `2019-05-30-welcome/index.md`

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

![Docusaurus Plushie](./docusaurus-plushie-banner.jpeg)

The blog supports tags as well!

**And if you don't want a blog**: just delete this directory, and use `blog: false` in your Docusaurus config.

metadata.title: MDX Blog Post
metadata.description: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

blogPosts.content:
Blog posts support [Docusaurus Markdown features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features), such as [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/).

:::tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

```js
<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>
```

<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>

:::

metadata.title: Long Blog Post
metadata.description: This is the summary of a very long blog post,

blogPosts.content:
This is the summary of a very long blog post,

Use a `<!--` `truncate` `-->` comment to limit blog post size in the list view.

<!--truncate-->
